awd_titl_txt: SPX: SOPHIA: Support for Opportunistic Parallelism with Heterogeneous Intermittently-powered Accelerators
awd_abstract_narration:
The rise of the Internet of Things relies on increasingly mobile and numerous computing devices, for which battery-based or wired operation is not always feasible and for which energy-harvesting (e.g. solar power) operation may be preferable. There are increasingly important industrial, social, and governmental domains that will profit from adopting energy harvesting or hybrid power solutions, such as health introspection, smart cities, augmented reality sensing, assistive cyber-physical systems, security and defense monitoring, and emergency response, as well as natural synergies with green-computing. Energy-harvesting devices are expected to be numerous, but unreliable, and thus offer both an opportunity and challenge in their use as a parallel computing infrastructure. This project develops new interfaces spanning from software through hardware that allow energy-harvesting devices equipped with on-chip nonvolatile memory to be treated as parallel computing accelerators, while maintaining system level reliability. This project integrates research with education by training graduate students and undergraduate honors students in overcoming the cross-layer challenges, from circuits through system software, in utilizing computation platforms that experience frequent power interruptions.

This project addresses three open challenges in parallel computing using energy-harvesting powered systems: 1) A lack of coherence and synergy between hardware and software in terms of forward progress guarantees; 2) An overfocus on serial execution scenarios that has not lent itself to parallelism in energy-harvesting systems; and 3) the ad-hoc nature of previous efforts to explore the design space of architectural support for energy-harvesting systems. The project introduces four new foundational abstractions to address these open questions: 1) an unified, cross-layer hardware-software interface for metering and managing forward progress; 2) a set of fair and parallel forward progress metrics; 3) an exposed cross-layer interface for reasoning about approximate forward progress; and 4) an offload-based model for nonvolatile processors (NVPs), wherein NVPs can be viewed as accelerators for "opportunistic computation." Project results include the validation of these abstractions, a systematic mapping of the design space of hardware-supported approximate and heterogeneous energy-harvesting opportunistic computation accelerators, and the development and public distribution of the new software tools and simulation infrastructure necessary to model complex software systems executing on energy-harvesting accelerators.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The expansion of the Internet of Things relies on increasingly mobile and numerous computing devices, for which the availability of power and other necessary resources is an inherent challenge. Energy-harvesting devices, which are ubiquitously deployable, but unreliable, offer both an opportunity and challenge in their use as a parallel computing infrastructure. Importantly, they require new interfaces spanning hardware and software to effectively harness their potential. This project addressed three open challenges in parallel computing using energy-harvesting powered systems: 1) Unification of hardware and software interfaces, metrics, and guarantees; 2) Extending the focus of research from serial execution to parallelism in energy-harvesting systems; and 3) bringing a more systematic approach to exploring the design space of architectural support for energy-harvesting systems. To address these challenges, the project introduced and explored four new foundational abstractions centered around two key ideas: 1) An offload model where non-volatile processors or other limited availability hardware could be viewed as accelerators for ``opportunistic computation''; 2) a holistic revision of the hardware-software contract for forward progress guarantees focusing on a) a unified, cross-layer interface for metering and managing forward progress; b) fairness for parallel forward progress; and c) exposing sufficient cross-layer metrics for reasoning about approximate and speculative forward progress.

Project results include the proposal and evaluation of several systems and techniques for enhancing intermittent computing, new interfaces for offloading computation to sets of unreliable accelerators, the exploration of hybrid harvesting/powered systems for sustainable deployment, and the systematic exploration of several design spaces relevant to the design of both individual nodes and entire energy-harvesting networks. We leveraged our opportunistic computing abstraction to bring solar-powered continual learning to low-power smart camera deployments, enhance the completion rate and accuracy of multi-sensor body-area networks on human activity recognition tasks, and reduce the energy cost of computation within complex memory hierarchies. We explored the design space of nonvolatile enhancements to servers to enable a range of faster sleep-state recoveries at varying costs. We profiled embedded computing applications in the ultra-low-power domain, such as neuromorphic event camera processing, and developed higher accuracy and lower energy approaches suitable for energy-harvesting deployments. We explored the scheduling of variable-parallelism inference kernels on resistive memory crossbars in energy-harvesting scenarios and co-optimized the circuitry for energy conversion to match input power and load demand for higher efficiencies. Finally, we explored new nonvolatile memory devices and organizations, specifically, FeFET-based devices, suitable for building deeply-integrated non-volatile processor components.

This project's research and educational activities were supervised by all three PIs. The project was affected by the COVID pandemic from 2020 through 2021, and therefore no-cost extensions were used to complete the proposed tasks. Our major findings have resulted in 14+ publications, most of them in top outlets in the computer architecture and design automation areas. In addition to the project's research goals, a variety of education, student mentoring and outreach activities were carried out during the course of the project. These included the supervision, by project PIs, of undergraduate honors theses on synergistic topics, undergraduate and graduate student training in research fundamentals, and involving underrepresented students in research and education activities associated with the project. The project supported eight Ph.D. and three MS students partially/fully during the entire duration of the project.
